plugin._field_explanation:
1) DO NOT XSYNC THIS TAG DIRECTLY. Due to the nature of how this tag is processed, it is never loaded in-game. Instead, xsync the parent model_animation_graph tag. You can do this without checking out the parent model_animation_graph; just find the tag in question in Bonobo, right-click it and select 'Force XSync'.
2) Legacy events are generated by the parent model_animation_graph. They are generated when the model sidecar is imported, and the importer will try to resolve duplicated events with the frame_event_list. If you need to delete a legacy animation event (or audio/effect event or reference for that matter) it must be deleted from both the model_animation_graph tag AND the frame_event_list tag.
3) The internal pipeline process for animation events now is: - When a sidecar is imported, if animation, effect, or audio events exist, they are copied into the frame_event_list tag. If the event already exists in the frame_event_list, its values are retained. Otherwise, default values are assigned such that the event behaves exactly as it used to. For the event ID, it is assigned the word 'Legacy' with zero frame offset. - New frame events should be specified and saved in the frame_event_list tag (you're looking at it). - When the model_animation_graph is compiled, the processor opens the associated frame_event_list if one exists, reads and processes the data, and stores it back into the original model_animation_graph on the xbox (or cache file), so no additional runtime memory or processing time should be required.

_field_string_id.name: name^#Give this group of references a name.

_field_tag_reference_64.name: model#optional. only allow this event when used on this model

_field_string_id.name: model variant#optional. only allow this event when used on this model variant

_field_tag_reference_64.name: weapon#optional. only allow this event when this weapon is in use

_field_string_id.name: weapon variant#optional. only allow this event when this weapon variant is in use

_field_short_integer.name: frame offset#If a frame event is set, this number is relative to frame event, otherwise it's absolute.
frame offset#If a frame event is set, this number is relative to frame event, otherwise it's absolute.
frame offset#If a frame event is set, this number is relative to frame event, otherwise it's absolute.
